Operation 'updateEvidence' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details, missing_side_effects, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary 'Update evidence' is too generic and doesn't clarify the action (adding files). Description is verbose and scattered, making it difficult for AI agents to understand: (1) what inputs are required (evidenceId, evidenceType, fileIds), (2) what the operation actually does (adds files to evidence set), (3) critical state constraints (must be pre-contestation), and (4) the response format (204 with no body). Improved version clarifies the action, specifies required inputs with examples, explains the pre-contestation constraint as a critical side effect, and defines the success response format for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description:
This method is used by the seller to update an existing evidence set for a payment dispute with one or more evidence files. The unique identifier of the payment dispute is passed in as a path parameter, and unique identifiers for payment disputes can be retrieved with the getPaymentDisputeSummaries method.

Note: All evidence files should be uploaded using addEvidence and updateEvidence before the seller decides to contest the payment dispute. Once the seller has officially contested the dispute (using contestPaymentDispute or through My eBay), the addEvidence and updateEvidence methods can no longer be used. In the evidenceRequests array of the getPaymentDispute response, eBay prompts the seller with the type of evidence file(s) that will be needed to contest the payment dispute.

The unique identifier of the evidence set to update is specified through the evidenceId field, and the file(s) to add are identified through the files array in the request payload. The unique identifier for an evidence file is automatically generated and returned in the fileId field of the uploadEvidence response payload upon a successful call. Sellers must make sure to capture the fileId value for each evidence file that is uploaded with the uploadEvidence method.

The type of evidence being added should be specified in the evidenceType field. All files being added (if more than one) should correspond to this evidence type.

Upon a successful call, an http status code of 204 Success is returned. There is no response payload unless an error occurs. To verify that a new file is a part of the evidence set, the seller can use the fetchEvidenceContent method, passing in the proper evidenceId and fileId values.
data.summary_suggestion: Add evidence files to payment dispute
data.description_suggestion: Adds one or more evidence files to an existing evidence set for a payment dispute. The payment_dispute_id is provided as a path parameter. The request body must include the evidenceId of the evidence set to update, the evidenceType (e.g., PROOF_OF_DELIVERY, PROOF_OF_PAYMENT), and a files array containing fileId values of previously uploaded evidence files. Evidence files must be uploaded via uploadEvidence before calling this method. Important: Evidence can only be added before the dispute is officially contested via contestPaymentDispute or through My eBay. After contestation, this method cannot be used. Returns HTTP 204 No Content on success with no response body. Returns error details if validation fails or dispute is already contested.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Update evidence' is too generic and doesn't clarify the action (adding files). Description is verbose and scattered, making it difficult for AI agents to understand: (1) what inputs are required (evidenceId, evidenceType, fileIds), (2) what the operation actually does (adds files to evidence set), (3) critical state constraints (must be pre-contestation), and (4) the response format (204 with no body). Improved version clarifies the action, specifies required inputs with examples, explains the pre-contestation constraint as a critical side effect, and defines the success response format for better AI agent decision-making.

message: Operation 'getOrder' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_context. Missing summary entirely. Description is verbose and contains unnecessary implementation details (e.g., reference to getOrders call). Improved version is more concise, action-oriented, and clearly indicates what data is returned and when to use this operation for AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
Use this call to retrieve the contents of an order based on its unique identifier, orderId. This value was returned in the getOrders call's orders.orderId field when you searched for orders by creation date, modification date, or fulfillment status. Include the optional fieldGroups query parameter set to TAX_BREAKDOWN to return a breakdown of the taxes and fees.

The returned Order object contains information you can use to create and process fulfillments, including:
  • Information about the buyer and seller
  • Information about the order's line items
  • The plans for packaging, addressing and shipping the order
  • The status of payment, packaging, addressing, and shipping the order
  • A summary of monetary amounts specific to the order such as pricing, payments, and shipping costs
  • A summary of applied taxes and fees, and optionally a breakdown of each
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve order details by order identifier
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves complete details for a specific order using its unique orderId. Returns comprehensive Order object containing buyer and seller information, line items, fulfillment plans, payment status, shipping status, monetary amounts, and applied taxes/fees. Supports optional TAX_BREAKDOWN fieldGroup parameter to include detailed tax and fee breakdown. Use this operation to access full order information for fulfillment processing and order management.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description is verbose and contains unnecessary implementation details (e.g., reference to getOrders call). Improved version is more concise, action-oriented, and clearly indicates what data is returned and when to use this operation for AI agent interpretability.

message: Operation 'getOrders' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_context. Missing summary entirely. Description is overly verbose with redundant information. Improved version consolidates key filtering options, clarifies default behavior, and includes the important caveat about cancelStatus in a more concise manner for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description:
Use this method to search for and retrieve one or more orders based on their creation date, last modification date, or fulfillment status using the filter parameter. You can alternatively specify a list of orders using the orderIds parameter. Include the optional fieldGroups query parameter set to TAX_BREAKDOWN to return a breakdown of the taxes and fees. By default, when no filters are used this call returns all orders created within the last 90 days.

The returned Order objects contain information you can use to create and process fulfillments, including:
  • Information about the buyer and seller
  • Information about the order's line items
  • The plans for packaging, addressing and shipping the order
  • The status of payment, packaging, addressing, and shipping the order
  • A summary of monetary amounts specific to the order such as pricing, payments, and shipping costs
  • A summary of applied taxes and fees, and optionally a breakdown of each


Important: In this call, the cancelStatus.cancelRequests array is returned but is always empty. Use the getOrder call instead, which returns this array fully populated with information about any cancellation requests.
data.summary_suggestion: Search and retrieve orders by filter or identifiers
data.description_suggestion: Searches for and retrieves one or more orders filtered by creation date, modification date, fulfillment status, or specific orderIds. Returns collection of Order objects containing buyer/seller information, line items, fulfillment plans, payment and shipping status, monetary amounts, and taxes/fees. Defaults to orders created within last 90 days when no filters applied. Supports optional TAX_BREAKDOWN fieldGroup for detailed tax breakdown. Note: cancelStatus.cancelRequests array is always empty in this operation; use getOrder for populated cancellation request details.
data.reasoning: Missing summary entirely. Description is overly verbose with redundant information. Improved version consolidates key filtering options, clarifies default behavior, and includes the important caveat about cancelStatus in a more concise manner for better AI agent decision-making.

message: Operation 'issueRefund' has semantic quality issues: missing_context, missing_side_effects. Summary is too generic. Description contains HTML markup and verbose regulatory information that obscures the core operation. Improved version clarifies refund scope options, emphasizes asynchronous processing, provides clear guidance on status verification, and mentions regulatory requirements more concisely for better AI agent understanding of operation effects and requirements.

data.current_description:
Important! Due to EU & UK Payments regulatory requirements, an additional security verification via Digital Signatures is required for certain API calls that are made on behalf of EU/UK sellers, including issueRefund. Please refer to Digital Signatures for APIs to learn more on the impacted APIs and the process to create signatures to be included in the HTTP payload.


This method allows a seller to issue a full or partial refund to a buyer for an order. Full or partial refunds can be issued at the order level or line item level.

The refunds issued through this method are processed asynchronously, so the refund will not show as 'Refunded' right away. A seller will have to make a subsequent getOrder call to check the status of the refund. The status of an order refund can be found in the paymentSummary.refunds.refundStatus field of the getOrder response.
data.summary_suggestion: Issue full or partial refund to buyer
data.description_suggestion: Issues a full or partial refund to a buyer for a specified order. Supports refunds at order level or individual line item level. Refunds are processed asynchronously and will not immediately show as 'Refunded' status. Use getOrder operation to verify refund status via paymentSummary.refunds.refundStatus field. For EU/UK sellers, digital signature verification is required per regulatory requirements. Requires IssueRefundRequest payload with refund details.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic. Description contains HTML markup and verbose regulatory information that obscures the core operation. Improved version clarifies refund scope options, emphasizes asynchronous processing, provides clear guidance on status verification, and mentions regulatory requirements more concisely for better AI agent understanding of operation effects and requirements.

message: Operation 'createShippingFulfillment' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_context, missing_side_effects. Missing summary entirely. Description is verbose with unnecessary context about line items and components. Improved version is more action-oriented, clearly states inputs and outputs, and explains the side effect (fulfillmentId generation) for better AI agent understanding of when and how to use this operation.

data.current_description:
When you group an order's line items into one or more packages, each package requires a corresponding plan for handling, addressing, and shipping; this is a shipping fulfillment. For each package, execute this call once to generate a shipping fulfillment associated with that package.

Note: A single line item in an order can consist of multiple units of a purchased item, and one unit can consist of multiple parts or components. Although these components might be provided by the manufacturer in separate packaging, the seller must include all components of a given line item in the same package.

Before using this call for a given package, you must determine which line items are in the package. If the package has been shipped, you should provide the date of shipment in the request. If not provided, it will default to the current date and time.
data.summary_suggestion: Create shipping fulfillment for order package
data.description_suggestion: Creates a shipping fulfillment for a package within an order, establishing the plan for handling, addressing, and shipping. Requires specifying which line items are included in the package via ShippingFulfillmentDetails. All components of a single line item must be included in the same package. Optionally accepts shipment date; defaults to current date/time if not provided. Returns fulfillmentId for tracking. Execute once per package. Returns 201 Created status on success.

message: Operation 'fetchEvidenceContent' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary 'Get Payment Dispute Evidence File' is generic. Description is verbose with HTML formatting and unclear about the actual return value (binary file). Improved summary uses action verb 'Retrieve'. Improved description clarifies the three required parameters, their sources, the binary file return, and error conditions for better AI agent understanding of when and how to use this operation.

data.current_description:
This call retrieves a specific evidence file for a payment dispute. The following three identifying parameters are needed in the call URI:
  • payment_dispute_id: the identifier of the payment dispute. The identifier of each payment dispute is returned in the getPaymentDisputeSummaries response.
  • evidence_id: the identifier of the evidential file set. The identifier of an evidential file set for a payment dispute is returned under the evidence array in the getPaymentDispute response.
  • file_id: the identifier of an evidential file. This file must belong to the evidential file set identified through the evidence_id query parameter. The identifier of each evidential file is returned under the evidence.files array in the getPaymentDispute response.

An actual binary file is returned if the call is successful. An error will occur if any of three identifiers are invalid.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve evidence file for payment dispute
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a specific evidence file associated with a payment dispute. Requires three identifiers: payment_dispute_id (from getPaymentDisputeSummaries), evidence_id (from getPaymentDispute evidence array), and file_id (from getPaymentDispute evidence.files array). Returns the binary evidence file content. Returns an error if any identifier is invalid or the file_id does not belong to the specified evidence_id.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Get Payment Dispute Evidence File' is generic. Description is verbose with HTML formatting and unclear about the actual return value (binary file). Improved summary uses action verb 'Retrieve'. Improved description clarifies the three required parameters, their sources, the binary file return, and error conditions for better AI agent understanding of when and how to use this operation.

message: Operation 'getPaymentDisputeSummaries' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Original summary 'Search Payment Dispute by Filters' is vague about what is returned. Description lacks clarity on return value and pagination details. Improved summary specifies the action and key features. Improved description clarifies all filter options, their combinations, default behavior, pagination mechanism, and return type for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description:
This method is used retrieve one or more payment disputes filed against the seller. These payment disputes can be open or recently closed. The following filter types are available in the request payload to control the payment disputes that are returned:
  • Dispute filed against a specific order (order_id parameter is used)
  • Dispute(s) filed by a specific buyer (buyer_username parameter is used)
  • Dispute(s) filed within a specific date range (open_date_from and/or open_date_to parameters are used)
  • Disputes in a specific state (payment_dispute_status parameter is used)
More than one of these filter types can be used together. See the request payload request fields for more information about how each filter is used.

If none of the filters are used, all open and recently closed payment disputes are returned.

Pagination is also available. See the limit and offset fields for more information on how pagination is used for this method.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve payment disputes with filtering and pagination
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a paginated collection of payment disputes filed against the seller. Supports multiple filter types: order_id (specific order), buyer_username (specific buyer), open_date_from/open_date_to (date range), and payment_dispute_status (dispute state). Multiple filters can be combined. If no filters are provided, returns all open and recently closed disputes. Use limit and offset parameters for pagination. Returns OrderSearchPagedCollection containing matching payment dispute summaries.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Search Payment Dispute by Filters' is vague about what is returned. Description lacks clarity on return value and pagination details. Improved summary specifies the action and key features. Improved description clarifies all filter options, their combinations, default behavior, pagination mechanism, and return type for better AI agent decision-making.

message: Operation 'contestPaymentDispute' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description is verbose and lacks clarity on return value and state changes. Improved description consolidates key information: required parameters, prerequisite actions (evidence upload), critical side effect (locks evidence methods), return value, and guidance on evidence requirements for better AI agent understanding of operation flow and consequences.

data.current_description:
This method is used if the seller wishes to contest a payment dispute initiated by the buyer. The unique identifier of the payment dispute is passed in as a path parameter, and unique identifiers for payment disputes can be retrieved with the getPaymentDisputeSummaries method.

Note: Before contesting a payment dispute, the seller must upload all supporting files using the addEvidence and updateEvidence methods. Once the seller has officially contested the dispute (using contestPaymentDispute), the addEvidence and updateEvidence methods can no longer be used. In the evidenceRequests array of the getPaymentDispute response, eBay prompts the seller with the type of supporting file(s) that will be needed to contest the payment dispute.

If a seller decides to contest a payment dispute, that seller should be prepared to provide supporting documents such as proof of delivery, proof of authentication, or other documents. The type of supporting documents that the seller will provide will depend on why the buyer filed the payment dispute.

The revision field in the request payload is required, and the returnAddress field should be supplied if the seller is expecting the buyer to return the item. See the Request Payload section for more information on these fields.
data.description_suggestion: Contests a payment dispute on behalf of the seller. Requires payment_dispute_id (path parameter, from getPaymentDisputeSummaries) and request payload with revision field (required) and returnAddress field (if buyer return is expected). All supporting evidence files must be uploaded via addEvidence and updateEvidence before calling this method. After contesting, addEvidence and updateEvidence methods become unavailable. Returns the updated payment dispute with contested status. Consult evidenceRequests array in getPaymentDispute response for required evidence types.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description is verbose and lacks clarity on return value and state changes. Improved description consolidates key information: required parameters, prerequisite actions (evidence upload), critical side effect (locks evidence methods), return value, and guidance on evidence requirements for better AI agent understanding of operation flow and consequences.

data.current_description:
This method is used if the seller wishes to accept a payment dispute. The unique identifier of the payment dispute is passed in as a path parameter, and unique identifiers for payment disputes can be retrieved with the getPaymentDisputeSummaries method.

The revision field in the request payload is required, and the returnAddress field should be supplied if the seller is expecting the buyer to return the item. See the Request Payload section for more information on theste fields.

Requires payment_dispute_id (path parameter, from getPaymentDisputeSummaries) and request payload with revision field (required) and returnAddress field (if buyer return is expected). Accepting a dispute results in immediate resolution in favor of the buyer. Returns the updated payment dispute with accepted status.

message: Operation 'uploadEvidenceFile' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_context. Summary is clear and action-oriented. data.current_description:
This method is used to upload an evidence file for a contested payment dispute. The unique identifier of the payment dispute is passed in as a path parameter, and unique identifiers for payment disputes can be retrieved with the getPaymentDisputeSummaries method.

Note: The uploadEvidenceFile only uploads an encrypted, binary image file (using multipart/form-data HTTP request header), and does not have a JSON-based request payload.

Use 'file' as the name of the key that you use to upload the image file. The upload will not be successful if a different key name is used.

The three image formats supported at this time are .JPEG, .JPG, and .PNG.

After the file is successfully uploaded, the seller will need to grab the fileId value in the response payload to add this file to a new evidence set using the addEvidence method, or to add this file to an existing evidence set using the updateEvidence method.
data.description_suggestion: Uploads an encrypted binary evidence image file for a payment dispute. Requires payment_dispute_id (path parameter, from getPaymentDisputeSummaries) and multipart/form-data request with 'file' key containing the image. Supported formats: .JPEG, .JPG, .PNG. Returns fileId in response, which must be used with addEvidence or updateEvidence to associate the file with an evidence set. Upload must occur before contesting the dispute.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and action-oriented. Description is verbose with HTML formatting and unclear about the workflow. Improved description consolidates technical requirements (multipart/form-data, 'file' key, supported formats), clarifies the return value (fileId), explains the next steps in the workflow (addEvidence/updateEvidence), and emphasizes the timing constraint (before contesting) for better AI agent understanding.

message: Operation 'addEvidence' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_side_effects. Summary is clear but generic. Description is verbose and repetitive. Improved description clarifies the operation creates a new evidence set, specifies required inputs (files array, evidenceType), explains the return value (evidenceId) and its usage, emphasizes the timing constraint (before contesting), and references guidance on required evidence types for better AI agent workflow understanding.

data.current_description:
This method is used by the seller to add one or more evidence files to address a payment dispute initiated by the buyer. The unique identifier of the payment dispute is passed in as a path parameter, and unique identifiers for payment disputes can be retrieved with the getPaymentDisputeSummaries method.

Note: All evidence files should be uploaded using addEvidence and updateEvidence before the seller decides to contest the payment dispute. Once the seller has officially contested the dispute (using contestPaymentDispute or through My eBay), the addEvidence and updateEvidence methods can no longer be used. In the evidenceRequests array of the getPaymentDispute response, eBay prompts the seller with the type of evidence file(s) that will be needed to contest the payment dispute.

The file(s) to add are identified through the files array in the request payload. Adding one or more new evidence files for a payment dispute triggers the creation of an evidence file, and the unique identifier for the new evidence file is automatically generated and returned in the evidenceId field of the addEvidence response payload upon a successful call.

The type of evidence being added should be specified in the evidenceType field. All files being added (if more than one) should correspond to this evidence type.

Upon a successful call, an evidenceId value is returned in the response. This indicates that a new evidence set has been created for the payment dispute, and this evidence set includes the evidence file(s) that were passed in to the fileId array. The evidenceId value will be needed if the seller wishes to add to the evidence set by using the updateEvidence method, or if they want to retrieve a specific evidence file within the evidence set by using the fetchEvidenceContent method.
data.description_suggestion: Adds one or more evidence files to a payment dispute, creating a new evidence set. Requires payment_dispute_id (path parameter, from getPaymentDisputeSummaries), files array (previously uploaded via uploadEvidenceFile), and evidenceType (all files must match this type). Returns evidenceId for the newly created evidence set. This evidenceId is required for updateEvidence and fetchEvidenceContent operations. Must be called before contestPaymentDispute; after contesting, this method becomes unavailable. Consult evidenceRequests in getPaymentDispute for required evidence types.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear but generic. Description is verbose and repetitive. Improved description clarifies the operation creates a new evidence set, specifies required inputs (files array, evidenceType), explains the return value (evidenceId) and its usage, emphasizes the timing constraint (before contesting), and references guidance on required evidence types for better AI agent workflow understanding.
